Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Nucleon with Electromagnetic Probes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Protons are one of the basic building blocks of matter and even 100 years after their discovery, they are still not fully understood. In fact, the precise radius of the proton is a puzzle and multiple measurements of this quantity do not all agree. A precise measurement of a proton’s radius is important because it determines the interaction with, and cross-section for scattering, other particles. The proton’s radius even affects the atomic spectroscopy of the hydrogen atom, which is tightly linked to the value of the Rydberg constant that has been so critical to the interpretation of all atomic spectra, because the electron and proton wave functions overlap and the radius is an important parameter in determining the amount of overlap. In 2010, a measurement of the radius of the proton was made using muonic hydrogen (hydrogen where the electron has been replaced by a muon). This proved to be the most precise experimental determination of the proton radius ever made, but was massively inconsistent with the accepted value for the proton radius at that time. This became known as the Proton Radius Puzzle (PRP). Since its inception, many physicists have tried to resolve the PRP, to no avail. MUSE (the MUon proton Scattering Experiment) will make the world’s first measurement of the proton radius via elastic muon scattering at a precision which can address this 4% radius discrepancy.

The focus of this project is the supervision and maintenance of the data acquisition system which reads out the MUSE detector system; and the analysis of the resulting data to compare scattering cross sections, form factors, and radii, and to extract charge asymmetries. The MUSE experiment has been fully constructed and this project will support engineering runs to further calibrate and test the equipment, followed by 12 months of measurement. Measurements will take place in the Paul Scherer Institute PiM1 beam line, which affords a 3.3 MHz secondary beam with a mixture of pions, muons and electrons. The beam momenta will be approximately 117MeV/c, 160 MeV/c, and 210 MeV/c. These measurements will cover a Q2 range of 0.002 – 0.07 GeV2.

In the course of the above described activities, undergraduate students, PhD students, and postdoctoral researchers will be trained in the development of modern electronics systems and modern data analysis techniques. The PI will present this work as part of her involvement in the National Organizing Committee Chair Line of the Conferences for Undergraduate Women in Physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

In 2010, the CREMA collaboration released a new measurement of the size of the proton, the proton radius, measured using muonic hydrogen: hydrogen where the electron had been replaced by a muon.  This measurement was an order of magnitude more precise, but 4% smaller, than and completely inconsistent with, the accepted value of the proton radius. This discrepancy became known as the Proton Radius Puzzle.  

There have been many proposed solutions to the Proton Radius Puzzle, but, to date, no one has conculsively proved which radius is correct and why the other radius appears the way it does.  Many new measurements have been published, but these too are split between the smaller and larger radii, with some even in between, and so no conclusion can be reached.

This project supported the final commissioning and initial data taking of the MUon Proton Scattering Experiment detector system (MUSE). MUSE will measure the proton radius by scattering both muons and electrons simultaneously on protons. It will provide the first measurement of elastic muon scattering on the proton with sufficient precision to address the Proton Radius Puzzle, will be the first measurement to use both muons and electrons, and will be able to study particles of both positive and negative charges, which makes it unique. The MUSE system is fully commissioned, begun taking production data in 2022, and will continue to do so until 2025.

Once of the largest causes of uncertainty in the extraction of the proton radius is known as the "polarizability" of the proton. The polarizability of the proton describes how it deforms in response to an electromagnetic field. Polarizabilities can be extracted by scattering packets of high energy light, known as photons, from protons, in the process known as Compton scattering. By measuring the scattered photon distribution in energy and angle it is possible to extract the polarizability of the proton, and improve our understanding of its structure and dynamics. An analagous procedure can be used to study neutrons. This project involved measurements of Compton scattering within the A2 experiment at the MAMI accelerator in Mainz, Germany, and the High Intensity Gamma Source (HIGS) at the Triangle University Nuclear Lab (TUNL) in Durham, NC. These measurements have resulted in new extractions of the proton polarizabilities which have been published and new experiments planned for 2024. 

By measuring elastic muon and electron scattering on the proton, and Compton scattering on protons and neutrons, this project enables us to develop a better understanding of neutrons and protons, the major building blocks of all visible matter.

Broader Imapcts:

The proton radius puzzle recieved coverage in popular media such as the Huffington Post and New York Times - it captures the public's imagination and can result in increased interest in science and careers in science. The detctor system constructed for MUSE can be used at many other facilities after MUSE has completed.

In addition to supporting the experiments outlined above, this project supported the PI as a member of the American Physical Society Committee on the Status of Women in Physics (CSWP). As part of that responsibility, she began serving as the Chair of the Climate Site Visit Subcommittee of APS CSWP and APS Committee on Minorities. The PI restructured the Climate Site Visit Subcommittee to make it more effective and to allow the Climate Site Visit program to be more sustainable. Climate Site Visits support departments, collaborations, and national labs to recruit and retain a more diverse workforce, broadening the diversity and inclusion in STEM, well aligned with the goals of NSF.
